importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the issue of limited VA therapy sessions was reported and brought to public attention.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The policy shift to limit therapy sessions began around 2021, especially under the administration of President Donald Trump and with the appointment of Doug Collins as VA Secretary, marking a significant period of change in VA mental health care delivery.

keyTakeAways: VA therapists and patients report that one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly terminated or limited, despite some patients requiring long-term mental health care.
The policy, introduced under earlier administrations and intensified since 2021, restricts therapy sessions to a set number (4–24), often ending before clinical need is met.
Providers face disciplinary action if they challenge session limits, including loss of privileges and mandatory written justifications for extending care.
Veterans with chronic conditions like PTSD may feel abandoned or re-traumatized when therapy is abruptly ended.
Some providers, including former VA psychologists, have resigned due to policy pressures, contributing to a growing staff shortage.
The American Psychological Association has acknowledged reports and is investigating whether the policy violates principles of individualized, recovery-oriented care.
Veterans often prefer long-term, trusted therapy over group therapy or reapplication, which can take months and may disrupt therapeutic progress.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Veterans receiving mental health care through the U.S. Veterans Affairs (VA) system are reporting that their one-on-one therapy sessions are being abruptly ended or limited, despite clinical need. This policy shift, intensified since 2021 under VA Secretary Doug Collins, restricts therapy to a set number of sessions (4–24), often without patient or provider input. Providers face disciplinary action if they extend care, and some have resigned due to frustration. Veterans like Michael and Jake Pannell express deep concern, citing trauma, abandonment, and re-traumatization. While some private sector practices limit sessions, experts including the American Psychological Association argue that long-term, individualized care is essential for chronic conditions like PTSD. The VA denies any systemic limits on care, but providers and patients report a significant decline in trust and continuity of care, raising serious questions about access, equity, and patient-centered treatment in VA mental health services.
title: VA Therapists and Patients Say Treatment Sessions Are Being Limited, Raising Alarm
